title: Australia Wanted to Catch Chinese Spies. Is This Really Whom It Had in Mind?
description: The police officers asked the man what he meant when he said that involving an Australian government minister in a charity event could benefit “us Chinese.” Was he talking about mainland China and the Chinese Communist Party, or the local Australian Chinese community? Depending on the answer, he faced up to 10 years in prison.

title: Was He Secretly Working for China? This Is What He Told Us.
description: Not long after we first met, the man said that if Australia was looking for Chinese spies, he was just the type of person they would be looking at — but the authorities would never “dare say I’m Chinese intelligence.”

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Does Having a Gun Make a Person Suspicious? Courts Aren’t Sure Now.
description: It was 2:30 a.m. on Valentine’s Day last year when a detective watching a live camera feed from a major Queens thoroughfare spotted a man in a minivan who appeared to be holding a gun.

title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: For Irish L.G.B.T.Q. New Yorkers, It’s Been a Long Way to Staten Island
description: This year, for the first time, every New York City borough will host a St. Patrick’s Day Parade that allows L.G.B.T.Q. groups, bringing a decades-long conflict to an end.

title: How a Marathoner and Sommelier Spends His Sundays
description: In New York wine industry circles, Yannick Benjamin is known as one of the top sommeliers. He learned his trade as a young man at places like Jean-Georges and Le Cirque. His work in hospitality took on a new meaning in 2003, when he was in a car accident at age 25 and became paralyzed from the waist down.

title: Menendez Leaves Re-Election Plans Murky, But Dormant Campaign Gives Hints
description: Plagued by legal trouble and abandoned by his allies, Senator Robert Menendez has made clear what he will not do: quit before his term is over in January.

title: Stalling: A Time-Tested Legal Strategy That Keeps Working for Trump
description: The schedule seemed stacked against Donald J. Trump: four criminal trials in four cities, all in the same year he is running for president.

title: ‘No Water in the Hydrants’: Communities Left Defenseless Against Chile’s Deadliest Wildfire
description: Weeks after Chile’s deadliest wildfire, some firefighters and residents said a lack of water to fire hydrants had hampered efforts to combat the inferno that destroyed thousands of homes and killed 134.

title: It’s a Visual Effects Extravaganza, but There’s Not an Explosion in Sight
description: A woman crosses a bustling street at night. Cars pass noisily. A streetcar cruises by. Behind her, we see twinkling streetlights, a cinema marquee, towering neon signs. It rained earlier; the roads are still wet. It’s Mexico City in the early 1970s, and it feels vibrantly alive.

title: You’re Not Being Gaslit, Says a New Book. (Or Are You?)
description: Don’t be so sensitive.

title: Ankle Monitors and Curfews: Inside Biden’s New Tracking System for Migrant Families
description: On a recent evening in California, a woman named Sandra was at a birthday party with her 15-year-old son when she glanced at the clock.

title: A Sophomore Novel About a Laid-Off Librarian With Obsessive Tendencies
description: When she loses her job at a library in a small Maine town, Maeve, the middle-aged protagonist of Sarah Braunstein’s bracing second novel, “Bad Animals,” signs up for a free hour with a life coach. “I see that you’ve lived for others for a long time,” the woman tells her.

title: For Ytasha Womack, the Afrofuture Is Now
description: On Feb. 17, the Adler Planetarium in Chicago unveiled a new sky show called “Niyah and the Multiverse,” a blend of theoretical cosmology, Black culture and imagination. And as with many things Afrofuturistic, Ytasha Womack’s fingerprints are all over it.

title: Where Did Baseball Come of Age? Not Where You Might Think.
description: New York City is enduring a professional sports drought of epic proportions. Football, as currently played by the Giants and Jets, is essentially over by Thanksgiving, with both clubs eliminated from playoff contention. None of New York’s three regional hockey teams has hoisted the Stanley Cup in the past 20 years, and basketball is drier still. The Knicks last won an N.B.A. championship in 1973, when the embattled Richard Nixon was president. The Brooklyn Nets, a haven for feuding superstars, have yet to reach the finals.

title: A Powerful Debut Novel About Rape Culture in the Workplace
description: In the middle of Ela Lee’s smart, compulsively readable debut novel, “Jaded,” a human resources employee assures a young lawyer named Jade: “As you know, we take all allegations of sexual misconduct very seriously.” They’re familiar words, but what do they mean in practice? Has the #MeToo movement changed anything? “Jaded” explores one millennial’s experience as she finds out the hard way.

title: They Fell in Love During the Pandemic. Then Things Changed.
description: For some people, it wasn’t easy being single during the early days of the pandemic. Many rushed into relationships, seeking company and comfort in another person — even if the match wasn’t quite right.

title: I Asked My Mom if She Was Prepared to Die
description: Recently, I had the following conversation with my 82-year-old mother, Mary:

title: Mike Lynch, Former U.K. Tech Mogul, Faces the Trial of His Life
description: Every morning in his townhouse in the tony San Francisco neighborhood of Pacific Heights, the man once referred to as Britain’s Bill Gates gets to work.

title: The Billionaire Taking on Disney Just Wants Some Respect
description: At age 81, with over four decades of dealmaking and corporate cage-rattling under his belt, Nelson Peltz would seem to have pretty much everything.

title: Republican Senate Slugfest in Ohio Fuels Jitters About Trump’s Candidate
description: Follow live updates on Tuesday’s primary elections.

title: Driving With Mr. Gil: A Retiree Teaches Afghan Women the Rules of the Road
description: Bibifatima Akhundzada wove a white Chevy Spark through downtown Modesto, Calif., on a recent morning, practicing turns, braking and navigating intersections.

title: Do I Have to Allow the Landlord to Do Building Repairs in My Apartment?
description: Q: I am a senior citizen and have lived for almost 50 years in a small building in Queens. My apartment is the only rent-stabilized unit in the building. The landlord is installing a new heating system in the building, which will involve major work in my apartment to install new pipes. The current system works well, and it appears the installation of a new system is mainly to bring in more rent for the landlord. Do I have to allow this work in my unit? Will my rent increase once the new heating system is functioning?

title: These Skiers Are Still Chasing Powder in Their 80s and 90s
description: It was a bluebird morning at the Alta Ski Area and Carol Bowling, 76, was looking for fresh powder.

title: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau Wonders About the Past 2 Million Years
description: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau wants people to step away from the abyss when it comes to climate action.

title: Health Misinformation Is Evolving. Here’s How to Spot It.
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday in a case that involves the Biden administration’s efforts to communicate with social media sites about posts officials believed made false or misleading claims about Covid-19 vaccines and the pandemic. While the case has primarily focused on a debate around free speech, it also has put a spotlight on the potential harms of medical misinformation — which experts say has become increasingly complex and difficult to identify.

title: Now Featured at Beauty Stores: Teens Driven by Social Media
description: Impelled in large part by TikTok to seek beauty products meant for adults, younger customers — teenagers and even preadolescents — are proving to be a mixed blessing for retailers like Sephora and Ulta.

title: ‘Practically Fasting for Months’: Gazans Struggle to Celebrate Ramadan
description: Every night during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, the man would come along Rawoand Altatar’s street, banging on his drum and calling out to the faithful to wake them up for suhoor, the predawn meal. His nightly mission used to be lit up by Ramadan lamps and twinkling decorations.

title: A Friendly Reminder: A.I. Work Isn’t Yours
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

title: Share of Democratic Registrations Is Declining, but What Does It Mean?
description: Newly registered voters, who are disproportionately young and nonwhite, have tended to lean Democratic.

title: Hitting the Slopes With a Wild, and Skilled, ‘old’ Bunch
description: A chairlift might just be the best place for a reporter to conduct an interview: It offers uninterrupted minutes of distraction-free conversation.

title: How Trump Is Scrambling to Raise Cash
description: As many as three nights a week, Donald J. Trump has been hosting private dinners at Mar-a-Lago, schmoozing with some of the Republican Party’s biggest financiers as he races to address a sizable cash shortfall against President Biden.

title: When Manahahtáanung Became European
description: Entering the New-York Historical Society from Central Park West, all visitors come upon a section of wampum belt and the kind of statement that in the last several years has become standard fare at cultural institutions.

title: A Shooter’s Parents Were Convicted of Manslaughter. What Happens Next?
description: When the prosecutor Karen McDonald decided to press criminal charges against the parents of the teenager who carried out the deadliest school shooting in Michigan’s history, even some members of her own staff expressed doubts, fearing the case was too ambitious to win.

title: Chile’s Deadliest Wildfire Is Said to Have Been Made Worse by a Lack of Water
description: As a fast-moving wildfire swept through the cities of Viña del Mar and Quilpué on Chile’s Pacific Coast last month, flames engulfed residents on the street, destroyed homes and overwhelmed the utility grid. Power shut off, communications went down and not enough water reached a critical line of defense: the fire hydrants.

title: In Occupied Ukraine, Casting a Vote (for Putin) as Armed Soldiers Watch
description: A new sign went up a few miles from the front line recently on the main billboard of an occupied town in Ukraine’s Luhansk region.

title: A Financial Crisis May Jeopardize Local News in Most of Atlantic Canada
description: Local news outlets have, of course, been in trouble in Canada and around the world for years. But now a lender has asked a Halifax court to dissolve the two companies that jointly own most of the newspapers in Atlantic Canada outside New Brunswick. And that has opened up the possibility that the region may end up without any legacy news outlets aside from broadcasters.

title: In Search of Spring
description: When does spring begin? For some, it’s the second Sunday in March, when we turn our clocks forward by an hour in the United States. For others, it’s when they first realize they’ve finished dinner and it’s still light out, or when the first crocuses poke up through the snow. Is it when you can go outside without a jacket and not feel a chill? When you pack away the down bedding and down jackets for another year? In the Northern Hemisphere, the vernal equinox will officially take place this Tuesday, March 19, at 11:06 p.m. Eastern.

title: India’s 2024 General Election: What to Know
description: India is holding its multiphase general elections from April 19 to June 1, in a vote that will determine the political direction of the world’s most populous nation for the next five years.

title: Part-Time Employees: The Plight of the Mistreated
description: To the Editor:

title: A Solution on North Korea Is There, if Biden Will Only Grasp It
description: How do you solve a problem like North Korea?

title: It’s Not You: Dating Apps Are Getting Worse
description: “The golden age of dating apps is over,” a friend told me at a bar on Super Bowl Sunday. As we waited for our drinks, she and another friend swiped through Bumble and Hinge, hunting for new faces and likes. Across the bar were two young men: phones out, apps open, clearly doing the exact same thing. Never did the duos meet.

title: America Owes a Historical Debt to Haiti
description: Despite the violence and political turmoil in Haiti, New York Times Opinion columnist Lydia Polgreen argues that this might be the tipping point that finally brings peace to that island nation. U.S. interference in Haiti has long been criticized, and in this audio essay, she says we finally have a chance to repair the damage we’ve done and help set the country back on a course toward dignity and democracy: “Just because there is this long history of failure doesn’t mean that success is not possible.”

title: Covid Precautions Are Still With Us. Just Look Down.
description: In the early days of the Covid pandemic, public health experts announced that maintaining a distance of six feet between yourself and other people would help prevent the spread of the virus. Seemingly overnight, stickers began to appear on the floors of grocery stores, post offices, pharmacies, and other public spaces, as well as the sidewalks in front of them. Placed six feet apart, they helped us navigate the directive to distance ourselves, indicating where we should stand to be safe.

title: President Biden, You Have Leverage That Can Save Lives in Gaza. Please Use It.
description: President Biden is sounding tougher toward Israel these days and showing more compassion for people starving in Gaza. “There are a lot of innocent people who are in trouble and dying,” Biden said. “And it’s got to stop.”

title: Unprepared for What Has Already Happened
description: Stories of people waking up to the fact that the world has suddenly changed.

title: In Paris, the Olympics Clean Up Their Act
description: How do you produce a global sporting event, with millions of people swooping down on one city, in the age of global warming?

title: 2 Novels to Make You Sweat and Shiver
description: Dear readers,

title: Does Everyone Want to Be on the ‘Mommy Track’?
description: When I caught up recently with Liz Koelsch, one of the moms that my friend Jessica Bennett profiled for our 2021 “primal scream” project — a look at motherhood during the pandemic’s peak — a lot had changed in her life. In the four years since Covid-19 was declared a national emergency, Koelsch, who was a single mom when we first met her, got married to a great guy. She completed an associate degree in paralegal studies. And she’s finally happy at work because she has moved to a job that is mostly remote and her boss is “all about time flexibility.”

title: Examining Trump’s Alternate Reality Pitch
description: Aside from falsely insisting that he did not lose the 2020 election, former President Donald J. Trump has peddled a related set of theories centered on one question: What would the world have looked like had he stayed in office?

title: Landline Users Remain Proudly ‘Old-Fashioned’ in the Digital Age
description: When millions of AT&T customers across the country briefly lost their cellphone service last month, Francella Jackson, 61, of Fairview Heights, Ill., said she picked up her well-worn Southwestern Bell push-button landline phone and called her friends “just so we could laugh at the people who could not use their phones.”

title: Kellyanne Conway Has Some Weak Advice for Her Party
description: It is beyond obvious at this point that abortion is the Achilles’ heel of the Republican Party. The prospect of a national abortion ban almost certainly helped Democrats stave off a red wave in the 2022 midterm elections and assisted them the following year in statewide and state legislative races in Virginia and Kentucky. The prospect of abortion bans has also pushed voters in states such as Ohio and Michigan to approve sweeping affirmations of reproductive freedom in their state Constitutions. And abortion looms over the 2024 race, as well; Democrats will spend countless millions to tell Americans that a vote for Trump, or any Republican on the ballot, is a vote for a national abortion ban.

title: Americans Invested Billions in Chinese Companies. Now Their Money Is Stuck.
description: When investors talk about “zombie” companies, they’re usually referring to distressed start-ups that are hobbling along, unable to grow and unlikely to ever return the money they’ve raised.

title: When Medicaid Comes After the Family Home
description: The letter came from the state department of human services in July 2021. It expressed condolences for the loss of the recipient’s mother, who had died a few weeks earlier at 88.

title: U.N. Documents More Than Two Dozen Attacks on Gazans Waiting for Aid Since January
description: The United Nations human rights office has documented more than two dozen attacks on Gazans waiting for desperately needed aid since January, with hunger spreading as a result of Israel’s near complete siege, preventing most food and water from entering the tiny enclave.

title: Irish Cream Coffee Cake
description: I always get a kick from cooking with booze. “Shots!” I’ll announce to nobody in particular as I add the tequila for salted margarita bars. And, without fail, “one for you, one for me” as I deglaze my skillet with a glass of white wine.

title: The Tinge of Stained Glass
description: “The New York Times is a university — one of the greatest universities in the world — with its doors open to whoso runs and reads at a tuition fee of two cents a day,” The Times declared in 1924 in a booklet called, “The Making of a Great Newspaper.”

title: 3 People Fatally Shot in Two Pennsylvania Township Homes, Police Say
description: Three people were fatally shot on Saturday morning at two separate residences in Falls Township in Pennsylvania, according to the authorities, who said the gunman fled and was tracked to Trenton, N.J., where he eventually surrendered.

title: Five Ways Buying and Selling a House Could Change
description: A settlement reached this week threatens to strike a blow to an established standard of residential real estate: the 6 percent sales commission. It also will change who pays it. The deal, reached after a yearslong court battle initially brought by a group of home sellers in Missouri, calls for the powerful National Association of Realtors, which has long regulated the way U.S. homes are sold, to amend its rules on how Realtors for sellers and buyers are compensated.

title: Authorities Seize Alligator Being Held Illegally in Home Near Buffalo
description: The alligator’s name was Albert Edward.

title: Rebellious Russians Stage Daring Attacks From Ukraine on Russian Soil
description: Gathered in a Ukrainian farmhouse, soldiers checked their kits: rifles, machine guns, grenade launchers, spare batteries for radios, red and white flashlights, all that would be needed for a stealthy and daring night assault across the border into Russia.

title: Larry H. Parker, Injury Lawyer Who Promised to ‘Fight for You,’ Dies at 75
description: Larry H. Parker, an accident and personal injury lawyer whose television commercials promised he’d “fight for you,” becoming staples in living rooms across Los Angeles, died on March 6 in San Juan Capistrano, Calif. He was 75.

title: All Over the Map
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

title: After Another Subway Shooting, New York Wrestles With Question of Safety
description: The subway crime that Jimmy Sumampow had been hearing about in recent years — as well as his own experience — had already led him to make plans to leave New York City. Then, on Friday, he saw a video online of the shooting on an A train this week.

title: First Sea-Borne Aid Reaches Gaza Amid Fears About Security and Malnutrition
description: The first shipment of aid to reach Gaza by sea in almost two decades was fully unloaded on Saturday on a makeshift jetty in the Mediterranean, marking a milestone in a venture that Western officials hope will ease the enclave’s worsening food deprivation.

title: Colorado Man Died From Venomous Gila Monster Bite, Autopsy Confirms
description: An autopsy report revealed that a pet Gila monster’s venomous bite contributed to a Colorado man’s death in February in what an expert described as “an incredibly rare” fatality caused by one of the desert lizards.

title: Haitian Migrant in Massachusetts Is Charged With Raping a Teenager
description: A Haitian migrant has been charged with raping a 15-year-old girl at a hotel serving as a migrant shelter in Massachusetts, authorities said Thursday.

title: Trump Says Some Migrants Are ‘Not People’ and Predicts a ‘Blood Bath’ if He Loses
description: Former President Donald J. Trump, at an event on Saturday ostensibly meant to boost his preferred candidate in Ohio’s Republican Senate primary race, gave a freewheeling speech in which he used dehumanizing language to describe immigrants, maintained a steady stream of insults and vulgarities and predicted that the United States would never have another election if he did not win in November.

title: Russians Know Putin Will Be Re-Elected, but Many Worry What Comes Next
description: Maria and her husband, Aleksandr, are certain that President Vladimir V. Putin will secure a fifth term as Russia’s leader in the presidential election this weekend.

title: Corrections: March 17, 2024
description: A headline with an article on Saturday about a violent altercation on a subway line in Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the condition of the man who was shot in the head. He is in critical but stable condition. He was not killed.

title: Will Mexico’s Claudia Sheinbaum, a Jewish Woman, Blaze a Trail or Follow One?
description: Mexico’s presidential campaign is well underway and if the polls are to be believed, Claudia Sheinbaum, a physicist and candidate of the left-leaning ruling Morena party, could be the country’s next president. Ms. Sheinbaum, who is of Jewish descent, holds a staggering 30 percentage point lead over Xóchitl Gálvez, a tech entrepreneur of Indigenous descent. However, the election is not until June 2, and politics, like life, is full of surprises.
