title: Another Wayward Container Ship Shows World Trade’s Fragility
description: Even before an enormous container ship rammed a bridge in Baltimore in the early hours of Tuesday, sending the span hurtling into the Patapsco River, and halting cargo traffic at a major American port, there was ample reason to worry about the troubles dogging the global supply chain.

title: A Murderer in the Family
description: It is not uncommon for novelists to deal with speculation about how much of their own lives makes its way into their fiction. The typical response is to deflect, with some version of how we are in all our books, and leave it at that.

title: Overlooked No More: Henrietta Leavitt, Who Unraveled Mysteries of the Stars
description: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

title: Trump’s Social Media Company Opens New Avenue for Conflicts of Interest
description: When former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company went public this week, supporters and investors betting on Mr. Trump’s political success helped drive the value of a loss-making firm through the roof. Mr. Trump ended the first day of public trading $4.6 billion richer on paper.

title: Buttigieg Outlines Urgent Effort to Restore Access to Port of Baltimore
description: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg emphasized on Wednesday the challenges facing federal officials as they strategized how to clear the rubble of the Francis Scott Key Bridge and restore access to the Port of Baltimore.

title: Thursday Briefing: Russia’s Online Attack on Ukraine Aid
description: Russia has intensified its spread of online disinformation in an effort to derail military funding in the U.S. and Europe for Ukraine, according to experts and intelligence assessments. The campaign largely uses harder-to-trace technologies to amplify arguments for isolationism ahead of the U.S. elections.

title: Joseph I. Lieberman, Senator and Vice-Presidential Nominee, Dies at 82
description: Joseph I. Lieberman, Connecticut’s four-term United States senator and Vice President Al Gore’s Democratic running mate in the 2000 presidential election, which was won by George W. Bush and Dick Cheney when the Supreme Court halted a Florida ballot recount, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: The U.S.’s First Congestion Tolls Were Approved in New York City
description: Transit officials in New York City voted today to approve a program aimed at curbing traffic and pollution by imposing hefty new fees on drivers entering Manhattan’s busiest areas. The tolling program, which still faces legal challenges, could begin as early as mid-June — making New York the first American city to adopt a comprehensive congestion pricing system.

title: Sean Combs’s Legal Troubles: What We Know
description: Since federal agents raided two of Sean Combs’s homes in Los Angeles and the Miami area this week, the investigation into the hip-hop mogul has become the subject of intense public interest and speculation.

title: Lil Jon: The Popcast (Deluxe) Interview
description: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, features an interview with the hip-hop and EDM legend Lil Jon in conversation about:

title: Seeking Balance, Tripping Up
description: The news that NBC had hired and then abruptly cut ties with the former Republican Party chair Ronna McDaniel this week may feel like a flashback for TV insiders and viewers.

title: U.S. Says Israel Has Agreed to Try to Reschedule Canceled Trip
description: A White House spokeswoman said on Wednesday that the Israeli government had agreed to try to reschedule a visit by a group of officials whose trip to Washington to discuss a possible assault on a key southern city in Gaza was scrapped over the U.S. decision not to veto a U.N. resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire.

title: Man Charged With Killing 4 in Stabbing Rampage Blames Drugs
description: A 22-year-old Illinois man charged with killing four people and injuring seven others in a stabbing and beating rampage told detectives that he had become paranoid after smoking marijuana given to him by one of the victims, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Fire, With Deaths Reported on Both Sides
description: Hezbollah militants fired dozens of rockets into northern Israel from Lebanon on Wednesday, in what they said was retaliation for an Israeli strike in southern Lebanon overnight.

title: Harvard Removes Binding of Human Skin From Book in Its Library
description: Of the roughly 20 million books in Harvard University’s libraries, one has long exerted a unique dark fascination, not for its contents, but for the material it was reputedly bound in: human skin.

title: Is There a Political Divide Between You and Your Parents?
description: As the 2024 election nears, parents and their teenage children and young adults are sometimes finding themselves divided on how they think about social issues, even if they identify with the same political party.

title: In Saga of NBC and Ronna McDaniel, Perks and Perils of Partisan Talk on TV
description: Trying to juice ratings in an election year, a major TV network hired a pair of provocative commentators from the political establishment to inject some spiky opinion into its otherwise-staid campaign coverage.

title: The Five Minutes That Brought Down the Francis Scott Key Bridge
description: Follow our live coverage of the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse in Baltimore.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Queens Man Who Brandished Scissors, Officials Say
description: A 19-year-old man who was in mental distress and called 911 seeking help was fatally shot by the police in his Queens home on Wednesday after, officials said, he threatened officers with a pair of scissors and they opened fire.

title: Officials Identify 2 Bridge Collapse Victims by ID and Fingerprint
description: Follow our live coverage of the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse in Baltimore.

title: John Eastman Should Lose Law License, Judge Finds
description: A judge in California recommended on Wednesday that the lawyer John Eastman be stripped of his law license, finding he had violated rules of professional ethics by persistently lying in his efforts to help former President Donald J. Trump maintain his grip on power after losing the 2020 election.

title: Trump Spreads Apparent Hoax in Attacking Judge’s Daughter
description: It was an explosive claim from Donald J. Trump, just weeks before his Manhattan criminal trial is set to begin: He assailed the judge’s daughter on Wednesday, saying she had used an image of the former president behind bars as a social media profile picture.

description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

description: Friends, allies and former rivals of Joseph I. Lieberman, who died on Wednesday, offered condolences and praise for the four-term senator from Connecticut who was once a standard-bearer of the Democratic Party.

title: Quotation of the Day: One Grieving Mother Steps Forward to Urge A Compromise on Guns
description: “I just thought, OK, Ev, let’s go — let’s go try something. Let’s go try to help people work together. Let’s see what we can do.”

title: Corrections: March 28, 2024
description: Bret Stephens’s column on Wednesday misidentified the country whose credibility with the West would be damaged if it was tied to Friday’s massacre at a concert hall outside Moscow. It is Ukraine, not Russia.

title: One Satellite Signal Rules Modern Life. What if Someone Knocks It Out?
description: The United States and China are locked in a new race, in space and on Earth, over a fundamental resource: time itself.

title: From Village to Prison to Africa’s Youngest Elected President
description: The first election that Bassirou Diomaye Faye ever won was the one that just made him the president-elect of Senegal.

title: Thursday Briefing
description: Russia is escalating its efforts to undermine military funding for Ukraine from the U.S. and Europe, according to disinformation experts and intelligence assessments. One of the Kremlin’s main tactics is amplifying online arguments for isolationism ahead of the U.S. elections.

title: What Is Going On in Pakistan?
description: For decades, Pakistan’s military has been the country’s most vital institution. Although it frequently intervened to oust elected governments, many Pakistanis saw this as salvation from the country’s blundering politicians. The army, it was thought, was the only force capable of holding the country together.

title: Word of the Day: baffled
description: The word baffled has appeared in 154 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 29 in “‘Spaceman’ Review: What Happened Here?” by Alissa Wilkinson:

title: Key Bridge Was Also Hit by a Ship in 1980, With Limited Damage
description: The massive cargo ship that lost control and slammed into a major Baltimore bridge on Tuesday was not the first to do so. The same bridge was also hit by a wayward cargo vessel in 1980.

title: Stephen Colbert Recaps the Ronna McDaniel Drama at NBC
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Why Russia’s Vast Security Services Fell Short on Deadly Attack
description: A day before the U.S. embassy in Moscow put out a rare public alert this month about a possible extremist attack at a Russian concert venue, the local C.I.A. station delivered a private warning to Russian officials that included at least one additional detail: The plot in question involved an offshoot of the Islamic State known as ISIS-K.

title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: How Long Does New York Take to Fix a Staircase? 10 Years and Counting.
description: Ten years ago, the agency overseeing the upkeep of the majestic New York State Capitol reported that the granite staircase leading to the main entrance was warped and bulging so badly that part of it might collapse at any moment.

title: Life on Both Sides of the Wall at Guantánamo Bay
description: It was a sunny day in May 2015 when Sarah Koenig and Dana Chivvis stepped off a U.S. military-chartered plane and onto the naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: The Connections Companion
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: The Challenge of Making New York’s 472 Subway Stations Safer
description: The scale of the New York City subway system is vast.

title: Are Glue Traps Too Cruel to Use in the Fight Against Mice and Rats?
description: When New Yorkers concern themselves with rodents, they typically focus on how to kill them. But a new law proposed in Albany this month aims to protect them from a long-used extermination method now increasingly seen as unduly cruel, even to a rat: trapping them with glue until they starve, die of dehydration or are dispatched by hand.

title: Rebecca Hall Redefines Stardom
description: Rebecca Hall stood in front of an easel, her face contemplative. She moved a paintbrush gently on a palette, then applied the paint to the canvas. This was in her studio, a converted barn next door to where Ms. Hall lives in upstate New York with her husband, the actor Morgan Spector, and their 5-year-old daughter, Ida.

title: Walking Away
description: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

title: As Relations Thaw, China Lifts Tariffs on Australian Wine
description: In a sign of easing tensions between Australia and China, China said Thursday that it would lift the tariffs it placed on Australian wine more than three years ago.

title: Deion Sanders Still Believes in ‘The Little Engine That Could’
description: Describe your ideal reading experience (when, where, what, how).

title: Sculpture Doesn’t Get Much Smaller Than This
description: At his day job, Lyndon J. Barrois Sr. uses high-tech software to create visual effects for movies like “Happy Feet” and “The Matrix: Revolutions.” But in his free time, he prefers working with a decidedly less sophisticated medium: discarded gum wrappers.

title: How a Middle-Aged Introvert Got His Groove Back
description: It began as ideas, good and bad, often do: in a bar.

title: Game Reviews: These Bonds Can Conquer Even Death
description: To discover the truth, a single mother and her spirited teen daughter take to the road. Two young brothers set off on a lethal journey to save their bedridden father. And passionate, longtime partners try to rid a New England town of a devastating supernatural scourge.

title: Like My Book Title? Thanks, I Borrowed It.
description: You see it everywhere, even if you don’t always recognize it: the literary allusion. Quick! Which two big novels of the past two years borrowed their titles from “Macbeth”? Nailing the answer — “Birnam Wood” and “Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow” — might make you feel a little smug.

title: The 25 Most Defining Pieces of Furniture From the Last 100 Years
description: How do we define furniture? It might seem like a silly question, but it’s one that kept coming up in October of last year, when, in a conference room on the 15th floor of The New York Times building, six experts — the architects and interior designers Rafael de Cárdenas and Daniel Romualdez; the Museum of Modern Art’s senior curator of architecture and design, Paola Antonelli; the actress and avid furniture collector Julianne Moore; the artist and sculptor Katie Stout; and T’s design and interiors director, Tom Delavan — gathered for nearly three hours to make a list of the most influential chairs, sofas and tables, as well as some less obvious household objects, from the past century.

title: Working With Your Hands Is Good for Your Brain
description: The human hand is a marvel of nature. No other creature on Earth, not even our closest primate relatives, has hands structured quite like ours, capable of such precise grasping and manipulation.

title: How Justice Thomas’s ‘Nearly Adopted Daughter’ Became His Law Clerk
description: The email went out to members of Justice Clarence Thomas’s law clerk network late last month celebrating his newest addition to an exclusive club. The justice’s selection needed no introduction.

title: South Korea’s Parliament Election 2024: What You Need to Know
description: South Korea​ns go to the polls on April 10 to select a new 300-member National Assembly. The parliamentary elections are widely seen as a midterm referendum on President Yoon Suk Yeol. They will also serve as a vote of confidence on the opposition Democratic Party, which has held majority control in the Assembly for the past four years.

title: ‘Shortcuts Everywhere’: How Boeing Favored Speed Over Quality
description: In February last year, a new Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 Max plane was on one of its first flights when an automated stabilizing system appeared to malfunction, forcing the pilots to make an emergency landing soon after they took off.

title: 36 Hours in Mumbai
description: Explore ancient caves, catch a concert in a former textile mill, feast on mangoes and go on a poetry crawl in this fast-changing Indian city.

title: T’s 25 Most Defining Pieces of Furniture From the Last 100 Years: Everything We Considered
description: Before sitting down to debate the 25 most defining pieces of furniture from the past 100 years, all six panelists — the curator Paola Antonelli; T’s design and interiors director, Tom Delavan; the actress and furniture collector Julianne Moore; the artist Katie Stout; and the architects and designers Daniel Romualdez and Rafael de Cárdenas — were asked to nominate about 10 objects apiece from which the list would be winnowed down. When coming up with his selections, Romualdez rightly figured that the others would include what he called “the anointed chairs.” Like Antonelli, he wanted to surprise readers, while also incorporating objects that, he says, “had become part of the vernacular.”

title: For Young Offenders in Maine, Justice Varies With Geography
description: Aroostook County, in Maine’s far north, is the largest county east of the Mississippi, a sparsely populated region of fields and forests with just two small cities and about 50 smaller towns. Police chiefs describe their jurisdictions as sleepy, with little serious crime.

title: He’s Got a Plan for Cities That Flood: Stop Fighting the Water
description: Cities around the world face a daunting challenge in the era of climate change: Supercharged rainstorms are turning streets into rivers, flooding subway systems and inundating residential neighborhoods, often with deadly consequences.

title: When Larry Met Jean-Michel
description: In October 1981, when the art dealer Larry Gagosian first laid eyes on a painting by Jean-Michel Basquiat, he had never heard of the artist. “My hair stood on end,” he said of seeing the 20-year-old’s work. Just six months later, when Basquiat opened a solo show at Gagosian’s gallery in West Hollywood, the place, Gagosian recalled in an interview, “was absolutely mobbed.”

title: ‘Winners and Losers’ as $20 Fast-Food Wage Nears in California
description: A decade ago, Jamie Bynum poured his life savings into a barbecue restaurant now tucked between a Thai eatery and a nutrition store in a Southern California strip mall.

title: ‘The Listener’ Review: The Side Effects of Pandemic Living
description: “The Listener” — directed by Steve Buscemi — opens with the sound of an unanswered phone and the thrum of a city before turning its lens on Tessa Thompson’s character, who lies in bed, staring upward, before beginning her late shift as the crisis helpline volunteer “Beth.” Written by Alessandro Camon and shot in 2021, this hushed drama takes on a pandemic many Americans experienced and continue to, even post-quarantine: loneliness.

title: ‘Wicked Little Letters’ Review: Prim, Proper and Profane
description: “This is more true than you’d think,” handwritten text informs us at the start of “Wicked Little Letters.” I looked it up, and they weren’t kidding. The movie involves tweaks and elisions to history, of course. But at least in its major outlines, the true story matches the film, in which a dour spinster named Edith Swan (Olivia Colman) and her raucous next-door neighbor Rose Gooding (Jessie Buckley) tangle over a series of mysteriously obscene letters that started arriving at the homes of people in the English coast village of Littlehampton in 1920. As you may intuit, this movie belongs to a very particular subgenre summed up in one declaration: boy, small English towns are full of weirdos.

title: How Much Higher Are Your Post-Pandemic Property Taxes?
description: The median price for a single-family home in the United States rose about 40 percent from 2019 to 2022, peaking at $480,000 before receding to about $417,000 at the close of 2023. The higher home prices have led to higher property taxes, adding even more to a monthly housing budget. A recent study by CoreLogic found that from 2019 through 2023, the median U.S. single-family property-tax bill rose by about 24 percent, to about $2,826.

title: A Building With Possibilities, on East 77th Street, Is Listed for $18 Million
description: Maurice Kanbar never saw the sense in accepting things as they were. The lifelong inventor and entrepreneur, who died in 2022 at age 93, developed, among other things, a comb for “defuzzing” sweaters, New York’s first multiplex cinema, and Skyy vodka, which he — somewhat dubiously — claimed wouldn’t leave you with a hangover.

title: No Eclipse Plans? Try These Last-Minute Strategies.
description: On April 8, a total solar eclipse will blot out the sun for roughly 4,200 miles stretching from Mexico to Canada — a cosmic show that so much of North America won’t see again for about 20 years. Many made their plans to view it well in advance.

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Julia Perry, who would have turned 100 this month, achieved some real recognition during her lifetime, but — in a tale all too common for composers who aren’t white men — fell into obscurity after her death in 1979. There have been recent efforts to revive her works, including her Violin Concerto, written in the 1960s and now recorded by the Experiential Orchestra under James Blachly, with Curtis Stewart as the soloist.

title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and on Staten Island
description: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,140-square-foot apartment with an open floor plan, a breakfast bar, a dining alcove, a primary suite with a walk-in closet and a balcony on the 11th floor of a 19-story doorman building with a live-in super, a package room, shared laundry, a bike room, parking, a gym, a children’s playroom, a residents’ lounge and a waiting list for basement storage cages. James Michael Angelo, Christie’s International Real Estate, 917-373-8343; christiesrealestate.com

title: Is Threads the Good Place?
description: Once upon a time on social media, the nicest app of them all, Instagram, home to animal bloopers and filtered selfies, established a land called Threads, a hospitable alternative to the cursed X, Formerly Known as Twitter. X had been taken over by the Dark Lord Musk, he who reopened X’s gateway to its banished demons Donald Trump, Kanye West and Andrew Tate.

title: With This Ring, I Unwed
description: Last week, Emily Ratajkowski shared on Instagram that she had created a pair of “divorce rings” by remodeling the pear- and princess-cut diamonds from her toi et moi engagement ring into two separate rings. Alison Chemla, a New York-based jeweler and creative director at Alison Lou (who also crafted Ms. Ratajkowski’s original engagement ring), created the new pieces. The post has since received over one million likes.

title: The Ellis Island Museum Gets a Face-Lift
description: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why a construction trailer has arrived at the museum on Ellis Island. We’ll also get details on a significant vote on the congestion pricing plan.

title: How to Deal With a Narcissist
description: “Narcissist” is a word many of us throw around casually, using it to describe anyone from an energy vampire to a friend who posts too many selfies on Instagram. But as Ramani Durvasula makes clear in her best-selling book, “It’s Not You,” the people who actually fit the bill are more complicated, wily and attention-seeking than we might imagine. She focuses on the ones who fall in the middle of the spectrum — those toxic charmers who, she writes, give you “enough bad days to take a toll and enough good days to keep you hooked.”

title: The Menu That Has Made One José Andrés Restaurant Endure
description: One afternoon this January, I watched the celebrity chef José Andrés flip through the page proofs of his newest cookbook, “Zaytinya.” He had the pages spread out over the glass top of a custom-made foosball table inside the Washington, D.C., headquarters of the sprawling food group that bears his name. Here Andrés was like a king in his throne room. The José Andrés Group now directs more than 30 eateries — from a two-Michelin-starred restaurant to a food truck — as well as retail products, a podcast, newsletters and television programs. (His charitable organization, World Central Kitchen, runs through a separate nonprofit.)

title: How A.I. Chatbots Become Political
description: We may soon rely a lot on A.I. chatbots, so keeping an eye on their political leanings is becoming more and more important.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: A five-bedroom, four-bath house built in 1950 but fully remodeled this year, featuring an open kitchen with a center island, dining area and living rooms and a separate family room and bedroom suite, four other bedrooms, a finished basement and one-car attached garage, a deck and a fenced yard on 0.25 acres. Besmir Vatoci, Realty One Group Legend, 201-294-2885; realtyonegroup.com

title: ‘Hey, Meta, What Am I Looking At?’
description: What happens when a columnist and a reporter use A.I. glasses to scan groceries, monuments and zoo animals?

title: In Raymond Saunders’s Paintings, an Education on How to Rebel
description: As much as they are works of art, the assemblage-like paintings of Raymond Saunders are works of archaeology.

title: Kamala Harris’s Epic Fail in Puerto Rico
description: Kamala Harris arrived in San Juan, P.R., last Friday for her first official visit as vice president. The trip was meant, in part, to highlight the Biden administration’s dedication to aiding the island’s recovery. What unfolded instead was a revealing tableau of Democrats’ missteps and misjudgments.

title: Tired of Doomscrolling? Try Ringing a Doorbell for Fish.
description: When friends visit Aliza Haskal’s apartment in Syracuse, N.Y., she offers them gripping entertainment: a live feed from a camera six feet below the surface of a cloudy river in the Netherlands.

title: Meta’s Smart Glasses Are Becoming Artificially Intelligent. We Took Them for a Spin.
description: In a sign that the tech industry keeps getting weirder, Meta soon plans to release a big update that transforms the Ray-Ban Meta, its camera glasses that shoot videos, into a gadget seen only in sci-fi movies.

title: Bogus Election Fraud Claims Still Run Rampant in Maricopa County
description: Nearly four years after Joseph R. Biden Jr. flipped Arizona blue, the state — and in particular its largest county, Maricopa — remains a hub for debunked claims of election fraud.

title: What About the People Who Don’t Vote?
description: The people who don’t vote are often left out of the political conversation. Campaigns don’t spend much money on them, and the media doesn’t devote much coverage to them. But to understand a presidential contest like the 2024 race — one that threatens to be extremely close — we have to understand not just the people who show up to vote, but also those who sit out elections.

title: Biden, Fighting for Credit and Raising Cash, Gets Help From Clinton and Obama
description: President Biden will lock arms with two of his Democratic predecessors at a campaign fund-raising event on Thursday evening in New York City, a public display of support from the two men who understand like few others what he faces.

title: The Japanese Sensei Bringing Baseball to Brazil
description: Yukihiro Shimura always arrives first. He quietly puts on his baseball uniform. He rakes the dirt field meditatively. He picks up the coconut husks and dog poop. And, finally, when he finishes, he bows to Rio de Janeiro’s only baseball field.

title: What Author Would You Most Like to Meet?
description: Has a book ever made such a big impression on you that you felt a deep connection with the author? Perhaps you found it to be extremely moving, or you thought it spoke directly to your experiences in life.

title: Who Would Want to Go to a College Like This?
description: The moral panic about “woke” campuses has metastasized into actual legislation, and not just in the swampy idylls of Florida. Last week the governor of Alabama signed a bill that purports to limit the teaching of “divisive” topics in its colleges and universities. The bill is similar to Florida’s ban on diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives in public colleges, which was signed into law last May. Both are all-out attacks on learning by excommunicating liberal ideas from the classroom. Other state legislatures have also been busy. The Chronicle of Higher Education reports that Republican lawmakers have proposed 81 anti-D.E.I. bills across 28 states. (So far, 33 haven’t become law, and 11 have.)

title: A Simple New Technique Could Make Your Eggs More Humane
description: The egg industry hides a dark secret.

title: Before Beyoncé: Black Artists Who Crossed Over to Country
description: Beyoncé’s new album “Cowboy Carter” releases tonight at midnight, and still very little is known. She has released two songs from the record and a track list. “Texas Hold ’Em”  hit No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot Country Songs chart, making her the first Black woman to hold that spot. But of course Beyoncé is not the first Black pop artist to try her hand at the genre. Hank Shteamer, our music writer, spotlights other Black artists who helped pave the way to this moment.

title: 4 Takeaways About Boeing’s Quality Problems
description: Boeing has faced intense scrutiny and pressure since a panel blew off a 737 Max 9 shortly after the plane, an Alaska Airlines flight, took off on Jan. 5. The episode raised fresh questions about the quality of the planes the company produces several years after two Max 8 planes crashed, killing nearly 350 people.

title: Use Your Allusion: See How Many Literary References You Recognize
description: Put your cultural knowledge to the test with these 12 questions.

title: On the Upper West Side, a Good Kitchen and Room to Grow: Which Home Did They Choose?
description: Looking to explore a new neighborhood in Manhattan and create a better work setup, a couple embarked on a search for a prewar two-bedroom.

title: Biden Administration Finalizes Rule Curbing Use of Short-Term Health Plans
description: The Biden administration announced on Thursday that it had finalized a new regulation that curbs the use of short-term health insurance plans that do not comply with the Affordable Care Act, reversing a move by the Trump administration to give consumers more access to cheaper but skimpier plans.

title: The Many Ways Men’s Sweet 16 Players Are Being Paid
description: Every team in the Sweet 16 round has been touched by “name, image and likeness” rules, which allow student athletes to be paid for endorsements, appearances and other work.

title: The Dali Is a Big Ship. But Not the Biggest.
description: The ship that crashed into the bridge in Baltimore holds barely half of what some of the largest container ships these days can carry — a sign of how huge the industry has become.

title: The Overlooked Truths About Biden’s Age
description: In terms of optics and in terms of energy, I wish President Biden were younger. There’s no point in pretending otherwise. And from the casual conversations all around me and the formal polling of voters, I know I’m in robust company. A great many Americans consider his age unideal, and that belief is why there’s no wishing away the focus on it. The swell of attention to it over the past few months is more beginning than end. There are tsunamis yet to come.

title: The Newest Tech Start-Up Billionaire? Donald Trump.
description: Over the past few years, Donald Trump’s social media platform, Truth Social, has been dismissed as a money-losing boondoggle.

title: Inside the Scramble to Evacuate the Bridge, and an Investigation Into Boeing’s Safety Record
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Crisis-Hit British Museum Gets New Leader
description: The British Museum on Thursday named Nicholas Cullinan, an art historian who currently runs the National Portrait Gallery in London, as its new director, ending an unsettled period in which the august institution lacked a permanent leader.

title: The World’s Unpopular Leaders
description: By many measures, President Biden is very unpopular. Since at least World War II, no president has had a worse disapproval rating at this point in his term.

title: What We Know About Palestinians Detained in Israel
description: More than 9,000 Palestinians imprisoned under Israel’s military and national security laws are being held in Israeli detention facilities, the highest figure in more than a decade, according to rights groups, who say that many of the detainees are being held without charges and have been abused while in custody.

title: ‘Asphalt City’ Review: Arbiters of Life and Death
description: Two paramedics — Ollie Cross (Tye Sheridan), a wide-eyed rookie, and Gene Rutkovsky (Sean Penn), a gruff veteran of the trade — traverse the mean streets of East New York, Brooklyn, by ambulance in the solemn drama “Asphalt City.” Flooded with neon and sirens, the movie opens during Cross’s first nights on the corps, tracking his and his new partner’s efforts to provide care for an array of challenging patients.

title: ‘The Beautiful Game’ Review: A Different Kind of World Cup
description: It’s moderately surprising that it’s taken filmmakers two decades to concoct a heart-string-tugging underdog story out of the annual coed sport event known as the Homeless World Cup, a weeklong international competition featuring homeless soccer players.

title: ‘Lousy Carter’ Review: Blackboard Bungle
description: Death be not tragic in “Lousy Carter,” a repellently watchable curiosity from the Austin cult filmmaker Bob Byington. Carter (David Krumholtz) is a self-involved literature professor with little interest in his students, his family, and his past and present lovers. So when he’s given six months to live, no one cares. Turn the concept of a laugh-out-loud comedy inside-out and you’ll have a feel for Byington’s sense of humor: a sustained cruel hum, the room tone of a crypt.

title: ‘DogMan’ Review: Crackers for Animals
description: Drag queens, disability and dozens of canines converge in Luc Besson’s “DogMan,” which opens with a quotation from a 19th-century French poet and closes with a symbolic crucifixion. In between is the strangest, possibly silliest movie of the veteran director’s idiosyncratic career. It is also borderline brilliant.

title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

title: Life Magazine Will Come Back to, Well, Life
description: Life, the iconic photography-focused chronicler of the 20th century, has taken on many forms, including a weekly magazine, a website and the occasional special issue.

title: U.C. Berkeley Parents Hired Private Security to Patrol Near Campus
description: Some parents of students at the University of California, Berkeley, hired private security workers to patrol near the campus, something the school says should be left up to the campus police.

title: Just How Wet Has California’s Rainy Season Been?
description: On Sunday, California’s rainy season officially comes to an end.

title: Bold Tiles in 64 Different Shades
description: If Indiana Jones took a turn toward the elegant and developed an obsession with textiles, he might be a bit like Louis Barthélemy, the French illustrator and designer who travels to Africa and the Middle East to work with weavers and craftspeople who are skilled in traditional techniques. Ishkar, a London-based company that collaborates with NGOs and artisans to create job opportunities for those living in isolated areas of countries often affected by war, recently commissioned him to create a capsule collection with women weavers in Afghanistan. Barthélemy typically works with artisans in person to create tapestries or rugs but, since the Taliban retook power in 2021, he’s had to connect with the weavers remotely. At the start of their collaboration, Barthélemy asked the weavers to draw a place that symbolized beauty to them. Many of the women chose the 14th-century Bagh-e Babur (Babur’s Garden) in Kabul. Images from those drawings, and one by Barthélemy himself, were then combined to create the patterns for three different rugs. Each one took about six months for the women to hand knot from Ghazni Wool. They are, Barthélemy says, “a collective dream of an ancient paradise.” The rugs can be seen in London at Sunbury Workshops on Swanfield Street from April 24-26, and through September at the Ishkar flagship showroom; from about $4,000, ishkar.com.

title: Old Newspaper Stories Offer Clues to 19th-Century Shipwreck in Lake Michigan
description: On July 9, 1886, the steamship Milwaukee was crossing Lake Michigan on its way to the lakefront town of Muskegon, Mich., to pick up a load of lumber when disaster struck.

title: A Fiery Finale for a Rocket That Brings the Heat
description: The ignition of the Delta IV Heavy rocket is perhaps the most visually striking liftoff you’ll ever see — the rocket seemingly burns itself up on the launchpad before it heads to space. Now, the very last Delta IV Heavy ever is on the launchpad.

title: Lawsuits Accuse 2 Michigan Jails of Banning Family Visits to Increase Revenue
description: Two county jails in Michigan banned in-person family visits for inmates several years ago as a way to boost county revenues from the increased number of phone calls and electronic messaging that resulted, a pair of lawsuits filed this month claim.

title: The Revolutionary Power of Women’s Rage and Grief
description: An artist friend texted me recently, asking how to contend with the anger and sadness she was feeling about the state of the world. I can think of no better balm than the Museum of Modern Art’s Käthe Kollwitz retrospective, the first ever at a New York museum that encompasses this German artist’s groundbreaking prints and drawings and her sculpture, posters and magazine illustrations.

title: Biden Will Campaign Alongside Bill Clinton and Barack Obama
description: President Biden will depart Washington today for a two-day trip to New York, turning his attention away from swing states to campaign and raise funds in a liberal stronghold.

title: When Richard Serra’s Steel Curves Became a Memorial
description: After the yelling, the hearings, the lawsuit, the dismantlement, Richard Serra entered the last decade of the last century with his mind cast toward the classics.

title: The Last Coal-Fired Power Plants in New England Are to Close
description: The last two coal-fired power plants in New England are set to close by 2025 and 2028, ending the use of a fossil fuel that supplied electricity to the region for more than 50 years.

title: Health Concerns Mount for Migrant Children at Outdoor Waiting Sites
description: To Dr. Theresa Cheng, the scene was “apocalyptic.”

title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | April 10, 2024
description: The above graph was previously published in The New York Times. The data, which excludes both imports and exports, is a 2022 estimate made by Ember, an energy think tank. The hydroelectric category includes other renewable sources of power besides wind and solar. The oil category includes fossil fuels besides coal and gas.

title: Live Like Karl
description: Karl Lagerfeld was a mega-collector. Of high-collared white shirts (1,000). Of books (300,000). Of period décor (Art Deco, Memphis Group, 18th-century European). And of homes — at least 20, in Europe and in New York.

title: Metro Boomin Is Headed to No. 1 (Again). Here’s a Guide to His Music.
description: Since 2013, Metro Boomin has crafted the beats behind more than 75 songs that reached Billboard’s Hot 100, including 12 Top 10 hits. The Atlanta-via-St. Louis producer has turned contemporary radio into a shadowy world of nocturnal 808 drums and sinister synths while providing breakout moments for Atlanta rappers including Future, Migos and 21 Savage.

title: ‘A Chance to Live’: How 2 Families Faced a Catastrophic Birth Defect
description: Ashlee Wiseman, a waitress at a Sizzler in Idaho Falls, Idaho, was 10 weeks pregnant when a nurse phoned with crushing news: a test of fetal DNA in her blood had found that her baby girl had trisomy 18, a catastrophic genetic abnormality, and was unlikely to survive.

title: Are You Getting the Most Out of Your Sheet Pan?
description: Hello! It’s Eric Kim, reporting for duty and filling in for Mia Leimkuhler this week. How are we doing today?

title: U.S. Officials Order Better Tracking of a Political Flashpoint: America’s Diversity
description: The Biden administration ordered changes to a range of federal surveys on Thursday to gather more detailed information about the nation’s ethnic and racial makeup.

title: Valentino Enters Its Alessandro Michele Era
description: The song has stopped in at least one game of fashion musical chairs. Valentino has a new creative director: Alessandro Michele, the former Gucci designer who left that brand in 2022.

title: Ireland to Intervene in South Africa’s Genocide Case Against Israel at the World Court
description: Ireland plans to file an argument in South Africa’s genocide case against Israel at the International Court of Justice, according to the Irish government, making the move as the country has strongly condemned Israel’s actions against civilians in Gaza.

title: Matt Schlapp Accuser Dropped Groping Lawsuit After a $480,000 Settlement
description: A Republican operative who said he had been groped by Matt Schlapp, the head of one of the nation’s largest conservative advocacy groups, dropped his lawsuit against Mr. Schlapp after receiving a $480,000 settlement, according to three people familiar with the deal.

title: ‘On the Adamant’ Review: A Psychiatric Facility on the Seine
description: It’s hard to tell the difference between the patients and staff in “On the Adamant,” Nicolas Philibert’s documentary about an alternative psychiatric facility in Paris. The treatment center, located in a large houseboat with louvered windows, floats tranquilly on the Seine.

title: Sam Bankman-Fried Sentenced to 25 Years in Prison
description: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange who was convicted of stealing billions of dollars from customers, was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Thursday, capping an extraordinary saga that upended the crypto industry and became a cautionary tale of greed and hubris.

title: How Sam Bankman-Fried’s Sentence Compares With Other White-Collar Cases
description: Two years in prison for tax and securities violations. Eleven years for deceiving investors. A 150-year sentence for the largest Ponzi scheme in history.

title: What to Watch This Weekend: A Fun Historical Crime Drama
description: So much of “Manhunt” is a deft modern chase thriller that one can almost feel the phantom F.B.I. windbreakers. You’d swear you can hear a ’90s office phone ringing, or that someone’s face is lit only by their late-night computer session. Yes, there’s an investigator’s crazy wall, but those photos aren’t 8x10s. They’re milky tintypes, because it is 1865, and we’re chasing John Wilkes Booth.

title: At Tiffany’s Flagship, Luxe Art Helps Sell the Jewels
description: Now that tickets to the Museum of Modern Art are priced at an astonishing $30 apiece, you could be forgiven for timing your visits carefully, making sure that they count.

title: ‘Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire’ Review: Running Out of Steam
description: Nothing about “Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire” makes sense, which is not, on the face of it, a problem. We have not settled into cushy cinema seats with our comfortingly stale popcorn to engage in discourse about metaphors and science; we are here for the stars in the title. About that title: “Godzilla x Kong” (meant to echo various other titles in other, non-Hollywood Godzilla movies) could mean Godzilla times Kong, or Godzilla crossed with Kong, or Godzilla against Kong — some permutation of titans. Whatever it is, there will be punching. We are here for the punching.

title: Biden Administration Restores Wildlife Protections Weakened Under Trump
description: After three years of planning and navigating the slow bureaucracy of federal rule-making, the Biden administration is restoring a series of protections for imperiled animals and plants that had been loosened under President Donald J. Trump.

title: Credit Card Swipe Fees Are Going Down. Are Points Going With Them?
description: On Tuesday, the largest credit card companies in the United States reached an agreement with merchants to reduce the so-called swipe fees retailers pay for accepting credit card payments, potentially saving the retailers $30 billion.

title: New York Will Test Gun-Detecting Technology in Subway System, Mayor Says
description: Mayor Eric Adams on Thursday announced that New York City planned to test technology to detect guns in its subway system as officials seek to make transit riders feel safe after a deadly shoving attack earlier in the week.

title: Improvise With Swiss Chard
description: For almost two years, I had managed to avoid a New York inevitability: attending an improv comedy show. That streak came to an end this month.

title: Jenna Lyons Will Return to ‘Real Housewives of New York City’
description: It was never a given that Jenna Lyons would return for a second season of “Real Housewives of New York City.”

title: Robinhood’s Credit Card Offers 3% Cash Back. Can It Last?
description: Here’s the first thing to know about the new Robinhood credit card that promises 3 percent cash back on all purchases, without limits: Yesterday, when I asked Vlad Tenev, the company’s chief executive, to guarantee that it would stay at that level for 18 months, he would not.

title: They Were Punched and Took to TikTok
description: A series of viral videos from several young female TikTok users, who posted emotional dispatches about getting punched on city streets, caused concern this week about the topic among fans online.

title: When Sean Combs Was ‘Living the American Dream’
description: Long before he was accused of sexual misconduct in a series of lawsuits, and long before federal agents in military gear raided his homes in Miami and Los Angeles, Sean Combs was unforgivable.

title: Man Is Charged With Murder in Fatal Shooting of N.Y.P.D. Officer
description: A man was charged on Thursday with first-degree murder in the fatal shooting of Police Officer Jonathan Diller, the Queens district attorney announced.

title: Answers to All Your Burning Questions About Sunscreen
description: While most experts agree that you should wear sunscreen year-round to prevent damage from the sun, harmful ultraviolet rays are strongest during the late spring and early summer.

title: Palestinian Authority Forms New Cabinet, but Doubts Remain About Its Independence
description: The Palestinian Authority’s new prime minister presented his cabinet on Thursday amid skepticism over its ability to meet international pressure for reform given the power wielded by the president of nearly two decades, Mahmoud Abbas.

title: Our 7th Annual Student Podcast Contest
description: Do you listen to podcasts? Do you tune in to find out what’s happening in the world? To stay up-to-date on sports, music, film, fashion or TV? To get advice? To laugh? To hear a good story? To learn something new?

title: New Senate Leadership Tussle Is a Throwback to the Old Days
description: When Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and longest-serving Senate leader, decided to step aside from his leadership role at the end of the year, it signaled the turning of a new page in the chamber.

title: Germany’s Beloved Dachshund Could Be Threatened Under Breeding Bill
description: Dachshunds, the German dog breed known for their distinctive long bodies and short legs, face an uncertain future if proposed changes to an animal protection law are approved, Germany’s kennel club said.

title: ‘La Chimera’ Review: A Treasure Trove
description: Like the yellow brick road, the bright red thread in “La Chimera” winds through a world that is both dreamy and touched by magic. The thread has begun unraveling from a long knit dress worn by a woman beloved by the movie’s hero. It trails across the ground, flutters in the air and beguiles you, just like this film. And, like all loose threads — in fraying fabric and in certain stories — this slender cord tempts you to pull it, urging you to see what happens next.

title: Trump attends wake for slain N.Y.P.D. officer.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump attended a wake on Thursday honoring a New York City police officer who was killed in Queens during a traffic stop on Monday evening.

title: ‘Garbage Lasagna’: Dumps Are a Big Driver of Warming, Study Says
description: They’re vast expanses that can be as big as towns: open landfills where household waste ends up, whether it’s vegetable scraps or old appliances.

title: America’s Energy Needs and Climate Goals
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump’s Defense Team Argues First Amendment Prohibits Georgia Charges
description: Donald J. Trump’s lead defense lawyer in Georgia argued in court on Thursday that the former president’s criminal indictment should be dismissed because it was based on comments that Mr. Trump had made about the 2020 presidential election that were protected by the First Amendment.

title: Outcry in France as Principal Steps Down Over Head Scarf Incident
description: A Paris school principal’s decision to step down after he received online death threats over an incident involving a Muslim student’s head scarf has prompted national outrage this week in France.

title: Peter Eotvos, Evocative Modernist Composer and Conductor, Dies at 80
description: Peter Eotvos, a towering Hungarian composer and conductor who linked modernist traditions in 20th-century European music and whose multifaceted work was singularly evocative, died on Sunday at his home in Budapest. He was 80.

title: The Judge Cracks Down
description: For months, Donald Trump’s lawyers have approached his legal cases with performative aggression and a pugilistic style, peppering judges with mountains of motions, many of them filled with far-fetched claims. And the former president himself has often been a disruptive presence at the courthouse and on social media, going after witnesses, prosecutors and even the relatives of judges.

title: A Painter Inspired by Islamic Art and Rural New York Life
description: Uman’s vibrant abstract works, currently at Hauser & Wirth in London, are shaped by her childhood memories.

title: Review: In ‘Reality Show,’ Jerrod Carmichael Is Out and Open
description: Midway through “Jerrod Carmichael Reality Show,” the comedian tries to convince Jamar Neighbors, his longtime friend and fellow standup, to deepen his act by using his unhappy past as material. Neighbors, who prefers an energetic, joke-focused performance (his act includes doing back flips onstage), is skeptical about what he calls “therapy comedy.” Why should he dwell on his foster mother, he asks, when “Jeff Bezos is going to space”?

title: A First Step Toward a Global Price on Carbon
description: It didn’t make many headlines, but last week, at a meeting of the International Maritime Organization, something potentially world-changing happened.

title: Dal Is the Ultimate Comfort Food
description: One of my favorite Hindi terms is “ghar ka khaana.” It literally means “home food,” but it also encompasses the singular joy and unfussiness of meals made in your own kitchen — the dishes that remind you of childhood, the ones you won’t often find in restaurants.

title: House Republicans Demand Full Impeachment Trial for Mayorkas
description: Speaker Mike Johnson on Thursday wrote to Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, demanding that the Senate hold an impeachment trial next month of Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary. The speaker called plans to quickly dismiss the charges against Mr. Mayorkas “a violation of our constitutional order and an affront to the American people.”

title: One Problem With Making Bridges Stronger? Ships Getting Bigger.
description: As larger and faster container ships began to chug up the Delaware River in recent years, transportation officials feared the prospect of one going astray that would lead to a repeat, or worse, of what happened in 1969, when a tanker struck the Delaware Memorial Bridge and caused significant damage.

title: Putin Offers Both Reassurance and Threat on a Wider War
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has warned that if F-16 fighter jets supplied to Ukraine by its Western allies operated from airfields in other countries, the bases would be “legitimate targets” for attack.

title: Logan Lerman Honors Two Families in ‘We Were the Lucky Ones’
description: Logan Lerman has been an actor for more than two decades, starting at age 5, and he’s been sent a number of scripts about the Holocaust. They read as exploitative to him.

title: On Broadway, ‘Centering’ Antiracism Is Delightful
description: My 12-year-old daughter practically had to drag me into the musical “Six,” currently raging on Broadway, in which Henry VIII’s six wives all have their say about what happened to them. I wanted to see “Kimberly Akimbo.” I’m afraid I have lost touch with modern pop, and from a distance the whole “Six” premise sounded kind of unpromising to me (a singing Anne of Cleves?).

title: What We Know About the Crew on the Ship That Hit the Baltimore Bridge
description: The crew members of the cargo ship that crashed into Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge were still aboard Thursday, more than two days after the collision that collapsed the bridge and left six people dead.

title: Film Club: ‘Island in Between’
description: In “Island in Between,” an Oscar-nominated 19-minute Op-Docs video, the filmmaker S. Leo Chiang reflects on his relationship with Taiwan, the United States and China from the islands of Kinmen, just a few miles from mainland China. Having split the last 15 years of his life going between the three, Chiang says, “More and more, I feel like a kid whose parents are involved in a three-way custody battle — hostile, codependent, manipulative, each pair with their own dysfunctions. They all think they know what’s best for me. They don’t care what I want.”

title: Taiwan’s Top Diplomat Says U.S. Aid to Ukraine Is Critical for Deterring China
description: Joseph Wu, the foreign minister of Taiwan, said on Thursday that a halt in U.S. arms shipments to Ukraine would embolden China in its aggressions against Taiwan and fuel propaganda from Beijing that the United States is an unreliable partner.

title: Officials Say Hazardous Material Aboard Crashed Ship Poses No Threat
description: The ship that crashed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore this week was carrying 764 tons of hazardous materials — including some in containers that were damaged when the bridge collapsed — raising fears about pollution and safety.

title: Auto Industry Expects Minimal Disruption From Port Shutdown
description: Concerns about the impact of the Baltimore bridge collapse on auto imports and exports are beginning to ease as car companies turn to other ports along the East Coast.

title: How the Israel-Hamas War Has Roiled TikTok Internally
description: When Barak Herscowitz joined TikTok two years ago in the company’s Tel Aviv office, his role was to recruit Israeli government agencies and other public-sector groups to join the video service and take advantage of its popularity. His pitch: TikTok was a powerful communication tool and getting more influential in the country by the day.

title: Searching for the Ideal Fish Taco
description: In the business of reporting on and reacting to culture — whether it’s theater, film, music, books or restaurants — eventually something you write will end up in promotional advertising.

title: Linda Bean, an L.L. Bean Heir and a Conservative Donor, Dies at 82
description: Linda Bean, an heir to the Maine outdoor retailer L.L. Bean who created a company of her own to market other famous Maine products, chiefly lobster rolls and seaside rentals, and who was an outspoken conservative in a state with a tradition of favoring political independents, died on Saturday. She was 82.

title: Send the Hosts of ‘Serial’ Season 4 Your Questions About the Podcast
description: If you’ve listened to “Serial” before, you know that we’re interested in criminal justice stories. Our new season, which kicks off this week, is about Guantánamo — a justice system unlike any other. Guantánamo is the prison and court that the U.S. built after 9/11 to hold people suspected of being members of Al Qaeda and the Taliban.

title: U.K. Backsliding on Civil and Political Protections, U.N. Rights Body Says
description: An influential United Nations human rights body delivered a scathing assessment Thursday on the protection of civil rights in Britain, accusing the Conservative government of backsliding and urging the country to abandon its controversial legislation to send asylum seekers to Rwanda.

title: Teenagers on Saying ‘Like’
description: In “Where Did Our Strange Use of ‘Like’ Come From?” the Opinion columnist John McWhorter explores the evolution of the word “like,” a filler word that he says took “its confident perch in American English” in the late 1970s. Before then, people simply paused between thoughts.

title: Vernor Vinge, Innovative Science Fiction Novelist, Dies at 79
description: Vernor Vinge, a mathematician and prolific science fiction author who in the 1980s wrote a novella that offered an early glimpse of what became known as cyberspace, and who soon after that hypothesized that artificial intelligence would outstrip human intelligence, died on March 20 in the La Jolla area of San Diego. He was 79.

title: ‘They Never Came Home’: Bridge Collapse Casts a Pall Over Baltimore’s Hispanic Community
description: Jose López was one of the first in his family to leave Guatemala for a new life in the United States. He wanted work that would give him a better life. So in the early 2000s he found his way to Baltimore, a city where strivers have long found a home and where Mr. López made one for himself and his family.

title: Friday Briefing: Sam Bankman-Fried Gets 25 Years
description: Sam Bankman-Fried, who was convicted of stealing $8 billion from customers of his FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was sentenced to 25 years in prison. It was a significantly lighter sentence than the maximum penalty of 110 years that his charges carried, but was well above the six and a half years sought by his defense lawyers. Bankman-Fried was also ordered to forfeit $11.2 billion in assets.

title: Having Trouble With Your Homeowners Insurance? Tell Us.
description: We’re reporters who cover climate change for The Times and we want to hear about experiences with home insurance. The Times has reported that home insurance bills are rising and we want to learn about what that means for you and your community.

title: 17 New Books Coming in April
description: After decades in America, a Dominican writer named Alma Cruz “retires” to a scrappy piece of real estate she’s inherited in her homeland. But a riot of stories — historical, magical, irrepressible — are still fighting to be told, so she builds a graveyard where their spirits can rise once more.

title: Robert Moskowitz, Abstract Painter of New York’s Skyscrapers, Dies at 88
description: Robert Moskowitz, a painter who used the New York City skyline to stake out a unique position on the border of abstraction and representation, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: 8-Year-Old Survives Bus Plunge Off Bridge That Left 45 People Dead
description: An 8-year-old girl was the sole survivor after a bus carrying 46 people on their way to an Easter weekend pilgrimage in South Africa on Thursday plunged 165 feet from a bridge into a ravine and burst into flames, according to a local department of transportation.

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Our fiction recommendations this week include a “gleeful romp” of a series mystery, along with three novels by some heavy-hitting young writers: Téa Obreht, Helen Oyeyemi and Tommy Orange. (How heavy-hitting, and how young? Consider that Obreht was included in The New Yorker’s “20 Under 40” issue in 2010 — and she’s still under 40 today. So is Oyeyemi, who was one of Granta’s “Best Young British Novelists” in 2013, while Orange, at 42, has won the PEN/Hemingway Award, the John Leonard Prize and the American Book Award. The future is in good hands.)

title: Sam Bankman-Fried Was Sentenced to 25 Years in Prison
description: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, who was convicted of stealing $8 billion from his customers, was sentenced today to 25 years in prison. He was also ordered to forfeit $11.2 billion in assets.

title: ‘Cataclysmic Situation’ in Haiti Leaves 1,500 Dead in Gang Violence
description: Gang violence has killed more than 1,500 people in Haiti so far this year, the United Nations human rights office reported on Thursday, the result of what it described as a “cataclysmic situation” in the country.

title: Trump, Attending Wake of Slain N.Y.P.D. Officer, Pushes Campaign Message on Crime
description: As hundreds of police officers and family members stood outside a Long Island funeral home, former President Donald J. Trump attended on Thursday the wake of a New York City police officer who was killed in the line of duty days earlier.

title: The Great Struggle for Liberalism
description: In 1978, the Russian dissident Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn gave a commencement address at Harvard, warning us about the loss of American self-confidence and will. “A decline in courage may be the most striking feature that an outside observer notices in the West today,” he declared.

title: Bidenomics Is Making China Angry. That’s OK.
description: A persistent theme in Republican campaigning these past few years has been the effort to portray Democrats in general, and President Biden in particular, as being soft on China — in contrast to Donald Trump’s supposed toughness.

title: Fighting Rages Around Two Gaza Hospitals as Pressure on Israel Rises
description: Israeli troops and Hamas fighters waged deadly battles in and around two of the Gaza Strip’s major hospitals on Thursday as the Israeli government came under growing pressure at home and abroad to moderate its approach to a war that has devastated the enclave.

title: Florida Has Banned Kids Using Social Media, but It Won’t Be That Simple
description: My entire life I’ve seen a similar pattern. Older generations reflect on the deficiencies of “kids these days,” and they find something new to blame. The latest technology and new forms of entertainment are always bewitching our children. In my time, I’ve witnessed several distinct public panics over television, video games and music. They’ve all been overblown.

title: Force of Ship Impact Was on the Scale of a Rocket Launch
description: A Times analysis used preliminary data to estimate the force of the impact on the Baltimore bridge. It involved “more energy than you can really get your mind around,” an expert said.

title: Saudi Arabia, Lagging on Women’s Rights, Is to Lead U.N. Women’s Forum
description: Saudi Arabia won an uncontested bid to lead a United Nations body dedicated to women’s rights for the 2025 session, bringing condemnation from human rights groups that argued that the kingdom had an “abysmal” record on women’s empowerment.

title: 4 Presidents, 2 Events and a Preview of Campaign Clashes to Come
description: The epicenter of the presidential campaign shifted to New York on Thursday, as the incumbent president and three of his predecessors descended on the area for dueling events that illustrated the kinds of political clashes that could come to define the general election.

title: The Rent Was Too High So They Threw a Party
description: During the Harlem Renaissance, some Black people hosted rent parties, celebrations with an undercurrent of desperation in the face of racism and discrimination.

title: Review: ‘Tommy’ Goes Full Tilt in a Relentless Broadway Revival
description: That its plot makes no sense is not really the problem with “Tommy.” When it first appeared as a concept album, in 1969, it was, after all, billed as a rock opera. And let’s face it, if you’ve ever paid attention to its story unstoned, you’re going to have some questions, just as you might with “The Magic Flute.”

title: Sweet Message Bearer
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues

title: Variety: Marching Bands
description: MARCHING BANDS — This grid, which is wide open except for one black square in the center, has a little bit in common with a regular crossword puzzle, and a little bit that’s different. On the similar side, there are two sets of clues, and every letter is used by two entries. However, there are no spaces between words, and one set of clues solves to entries that run in four directions — down, across, up and backward. This makes for a fun challenge.

title: Shohei Ohtani Is Home and Focused on Baseball. Dodgers Fans Are Relieved.
description: The top deck of Dodger Stadium is far from the action but may have the best view in baseball. Straight ahead are the San Gabriel Mountains. During night games, as the sun goes down, the sky glows pink. Down below, the full choreography of the game is on display, offering a panoramic view shunned by the movie stars and moguls who fill the sections behind home plate.

title: A River Awakens, Bringing Green Magic to a Desert Town
description: Whenever there’s rain in the forecast for the desert town of Mparntwe, otherwise known as Alice Springs, the same question usually surfaces: “Do you think the Todd will flow?”

title: Woman Who Received 5-Year Sentence in Voter Fraud Case Is Acquitted
description: In a case that has prompted outrage from voting-rights activists for years, a Texas appeals court reversed itself on Thursday and acquitted a woman who had been sentenced to five years in prison for illegally casting a provisional ballot in the 2016 election.

title: Georgia Lawmakers Approve Tougher Rules on Immigration After Student’s Killing
description: Georgia lawmakers voted on Thursday to tighten the state’s already strict immigration laws in response to the killing of Laken Riley, a 22-year-old nursing student, whose death became ensnared in the broader fight over immigration policy after a man from Venezuela who entered the country illegally was charged with her murder.

title: Fish Stew and Black Fettuccine, an Unexpected Recipe for Love
description: It was Sept. 1, 2020, and Maxwell Dayvson Da Silva and Evgenia Satsuk were wearing masks during their first date at Leuca, an Italian restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He freaked her out just a bit when he asked her to lower her mask and kissed her.

title: He Expresses Himself Through Art. She Through Math.
description: The last weekend of February, Sharif Hussein Farrag, a ceramic artist, raced colorful clay rats that he sculpted and placed on motorized vehicles around a sports field outside the Santa Monica Airport.

title: He Offered Her a Seat at His Table, and Later, a Place in His Heart
description: If accidental matchmakers got Yelp reviews, Pamela Grace and Arnim Ludwig Kaiser would give five stars to the waitress who served them on Oct. 11, 2022, at Le Plaza-La Paillotte, a restaurant in Arles, France. A half-star deduction for one too many tableside visits might be justified, though.

title: After a Missed Connection, a Union of Mythic Proportions
description: Zachary Brian Lee Copeland’s dating app adventures in Washington, D.C., weren’t worthy of lunchtime discussion with his co-workers until the autumn of 2019, when he matched with Joelle Carissa Gamble on Hinge.

title: How I Learned to Trust (Some) Men
description: Too early in life, the male species began to fail me. As an adolescent, I was lied to, cheated on, harassed and assaulted. As a young adult, more of the same. Nevertheless, I ended up in a healthy marriage with a kind, trustworthy man. Sometimes I think it’s because of what happened that summer more than 30 years ago at the Vatican.

title: No Corrections: March 29, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Quotation of the Day: One Architect’s Advice for Flood-Prone Cities: Act as a Sponge Would
description: “You cannot fight water. You have to adapt to it.”

title: ‘Every Day Is Hard’: One Year Since Russia Jailed a U.S. Reporter
description: One year ago on Friday, Ella Milman and Mikhail Gershkovich received a chilling phone call from the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal. Their son, Evan, a foreign correspondent for The Journal who was on a reporting assignment in Russia, had missed his daily security check-in.

title: Scheming and Sex in a Queer King’s Court
description: Standing in a shadowy archway on a bridge leading into Broughton Castle in Oxfordshire, England, sheep nibbling the grass below, Julianne Moore curtsied deeply, lowering her eyes before a splendidly gowned woman. “Your Majesty,” she began, before being drowned out by a loud “baa” from the sheep. Moore burst out laughing, as did her fellow actress, Trine Dyrholm, who was playing Queen Anne of England. “Talk to the sheep!” Moore commanded the director, Oliver Hermanus. “Tell them we’re doing a TV mini-series!”

title: A Very Royal Scavenger Hunt
description: In 1933, a new craze took New York society by storm: the scavenger hunt. It began at a party that Elsa Maxwell, a prominent gossip columnist, threw at the Waldorf Astoria. Her guests were divided into small teams who competed against each other to obtain a list of items that included a live monkey, a red lantern and “the most beautiful woman in New York (not present at the party).”

title: Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’ Is Here, and It’s Much More Than Country
description: Beyoncé has gone country, sure … but it turns out that’s only the half of it.

title: Friday Briefing
description: One year ago today, the Russian authorities detained Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, and accused him of spying for the U.S. government. He is the first American reporter since the end of the Cold War to be held on espionage charges in Russia.

title: Putin’s Next Escalation Is Coming
description: In the wake of the terrorist attack at Moscow’s Crocus City Hall last Friday, which killed at least 143 people, Russia is in mourning. The country’s leaders, on the other hand, are doing something else: They’re plotting.

title: Word of the Day: extravaganza
description: The word extravaganza has appeared in 90 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 21 in “A Light Display With Many, but Not All, Glowing Reviews” by Ronda Kaysen:

title: Trump’s Stock Is Rising, and Seth Meyers Is Skeptical
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: The Connections Companion
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Inside a High-Stakes Fight to Limit Social Media’s Hold on Children
description: When New York’s governor and attorney general joined forces to pass a law trying to restrict social media companies’ ability to use algorithms to shape content for children, they expected Big Tech to put up a battle.

title: A Reporter Appraises the State of Real Estate
description: The American housing market is under renovation.

title: Watching
description: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

title: Breaking the Ramadan Fast With Some of Brooklyn’s Newest Arrivals
description: The migrants in Bed-Stuy are mostly from Sudan and West Africa, and they have energized the neighborhood’s Muslim community. They bring youthful crowds to its mosques and businesses, but are also in desperate need of assistance and basic services, including food, long-term housing and work authorization.

title: Glorious Germs, Ready for Their Close-Up
description: Open “Micrographia” (1665), the otherworldly illustrated treatise by the microscopist Robert Hooke, and you’ll see why scientists have gone smaller and smaller ever since.

title: A Twisty, Gloriously Grim Novel That Makes for Great Listening
description: THE ADVERSARY, by Michael Crummey. Read by Mary Lewis.

title: This Is the Way the World Ends (According to Novelists)
description: In the opening chapters of “2054,” a new thriller co-written by Elliot Ackerman and Adm. James Stavridis, the action shifts every page or two — from a private jet, to the White House, to a Ritz-Carlton hotel, to Capitol Hill and elsewhere. The short sections are titled with locations and time stamps (including time zones) to signify global scope and high stakes. We understand at once that this is a story too big to be told from one perspective.

title: From New England to Notre-Dame, a U.S. Carpenter Tends to a French Icon
description: Notre-Dame Cathedral sat in the pre-dawn chill like a spaceship docked in the heart of Paris, its exoskeleton of scaffolding lit by bright lights. Pink clouds appeared to the east as machinery hummed to life and workers started clambering around.

title: Rise of the Ronin Sends Players Into a Chaotic Japan
description: After decades of designing linear video game adventures such as the Ninja Gaiden and Nioh series, Team Ninja has dropped the guardrails and loosed players into an open world.

title: Our Bunnies, Ourselves
description: We have a complicated relationship with bunnies.

title: San Francisco’s ‘Twitter Menace’ or True Believer? He Might Be Both.
description: Under cathedral ceilings and soaring stained glass windows, Garry Tan clutched a microphone as he greeted a crowd of political centrists, including San Francisco’s mayor, local prosecutors and police brass.

title: A Harsh Mongolian Winter Leaves Millions of Livestock Dead
description: An unusually brutal winter in Mongolia has left much of the country’s grazing land frozen and snow-covered, starving or freezing millions of animals and upending thousands of lives in a country where a third of the population depends on herding and agriculture to make a living.

title: The Team Effort Behind One of Classical Music’s Greatest Hits
description: In 1916, the composer Gustav Holst took a young conductor, Adrian Boult, on a long walk through Kew Gardens and Richmond Park in London. A few years earlier, Boult had written to Holst asking whether he had composed any music for small orchestra that he could perform. On this day, though, they discussed a much grander prospect: a suite for large orchestra that would become “The Planets.”

title: An Idyll on the Shores of a Toxic Lake
description: There are two ways to experience the town of Bombay Beach, Calif., as a visitor: gawk at the spectacle or fall into the vortex. Thousands of tourists cruise through each year, often without getting out of their cars to see decaying art installations left over from an annual mid-March gathering of artists, photographers and documentarians known jokingly as the Bombay Beach Biennale. When I went to the town for the first time in 2021, I was looking for salvation in this weird desert town on the Salton Sea south of Palm Springs and Joshua Tree National Park. I dropped in, felt vibes and left with stories. I stared at the eccentric large-scale art, posted photos on Instagram of ruin porn and a hot pink sign on the beach that said, “If you’re stuck, call Kim.” I posed in front of a mountain of painted televisions, swung on a swing over the edge of the lake’s retreating shoreline and explored the half-buried, rusted-out cars that make up an abandoned ersatz drive-in movie theater. On that trip, it felt as if I were inside a “Mad Max” simulation, but I was only scratching the surface of the town.

title: Can Reed Hastings Disrupt Skiing?
description: On a Monday morning in early March, Reed Hastings, the billionaire co-founder and former chief executive of Netflix, clicked into the bindings on his snowboard and started off down one of the slopes at Powder Mountain, a ski area in Utah’s northeast corner. He quickly veered off the groomed trail into some well-spaced trees, and as he made turns over bumpy snow, you could hear his edges scratch against patches of ice.

title: The Anxiety of Watching Risk Takers Clash Over Life-or-Death Decisions
description: Spoilers follow.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Leaving Half a Banana Uneaten
description: Anthony writes: My wife loves fresh bananas. When she was pregnant, she wanted only half a banana at a time. Her solution? Take a knife and cut a banana in half while it was still attached to the bunch. She won’t eat the remaining half, so it hangs there, turning brown within hours. She gave birth three weeks ago, and her appetite has returned. But she continues to do this. Please make her stop.

title: A.I.-Generated Garbage Is Polluting Our Culture
description: Increasingly, mounds of synthetic A.I.-generated outputs drift across our feeds and our searches. The stakes go far beyond what’s on our screens. The entire culture is becoming affected by A.I.’s runoff, an insidious creep into our most important institutions.

title: Something Other Than Originalism Explains This Supreme Court
description: It is a sign of the polarizing nature of the current Supreme Court that even knowledgeable critics of its opinions make diametrically opposed arguments.

title: $900,000 Homes in Rome
description: This one-bedroom, one-bath apartment is on the top floor of a four-story 18th-century building near the Trevi Fountain. Built in the Renaissance style, it features cornices above the windows and wood shutters. An inscription above the main entry has the Latin motto, “Ne Gloriari Liberat Alienis Bonis” (“Do not boast of the merits of others”), taken from an ancient fable by Phaedrus.

title: The Rise of ‘Middle-Finger Politics’
description: Donald Trump can seem like a political anomaly. You sometimes hear people describe his connection with his base in quasi-mystical terms. But really, Trump is an example of an archetype — the right-wing populist showman — that recurs across time and place. There’s Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil, Boris Johnson in Britain, Javier Milei in Argentina. And there’s a long lineage of this type in the United States too.

title: ‘Romancing the Stone’ and Its Screenwriter’s Tragic Tale
description: Each day, before her waitressing shift began, Diane Thomas would plop herself onto the floor of her tiny Malibu studio apartment, in front of a low-slung desk, and begin typing.
